comment._content: In 1912, J. P. Morgan decided to demolish his building at 23 Wall Street and build a new office on the same site. The new building was four stories, therefore this is the demolition of the old building. (ref. wirednewyork.com/forum/archive/index.php/t-3610.html )

comment.author: 22427408@N00
comment._content: Here's a modern shot of the building that replaced the old Morgan building, now part of a condominium development, Downtown by Philippe Starck, named for French designer Philippe Starck.

comment.author: 34427466731@N01
comment._content: interesting that they'd demolish a building in order to rebuild something smaller.

comment.author: 8623220@N02
comment._content: Lifeasdaddy: Thank you for the information about the building. According to this New York Times article (May 1, 1913) the demolition started on April 30, 1913 and was supposed to continue for forty days: query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9906E0DA1F3AE633A... We will update the information and reload the description.

comment.author: 14936048@N07
comment._content: I don't know if this is true or not, but I had heard that Morgan had the building replaced with a smaller building merely to show off his wealth: that he could afford to purchase some of the most expensive real estate in the world and only put a four-story building on it.

comment.author: 34427466731@N01
comment._content:
The Great Photographicon - that's a very interesting rumour. i was looking through the new york times archives to see it they had information regarding this, and found the following quote:
"The plans as at present decided upon provide for a building of only two stories, but it will have the height of a four-story structure,as both of the floors will be of exceptional height. The foundations, however, will be sunk in bed to rock, sixty feet or below the surface, giving an opportunity of enlarging the building to thirty or forty stories, if required, in the future." New York Times - February 18, 1913
which makes me wonder how deep that basement ended up being and what the heck is down there today. i guess the idea was that this building would serve as the base for a skyscraper that never happened.
